unit.title: Week 1
unit.description: Introduction to Web Development, HTML and CSS

entries.title: Making and Saving Documents
entries.description:
Today's main topics are Git and HTML/CSS.

The session discuss git and GitHub workflows; valid HTML; and targeting HTML with CSS.

entries.title: Setting Expectations for a Successful Journey
entries.description:
In today's session, students will review the logistical details of the Bootcampâ€”including when and how to contact their Studenet Success Managers, and eligibiity requirements for career services. 

Students will also begin to tinker with the command line and, time allowing, HTML.

entries.title: Visual Architecture with CSS: Positioning Properties In-Depth
Introduction to Node
entries.description:
Today's class introduces the ideas behind servers; clients; and the request-response cycle.

Students will also use Node to write applications that run outside of the browser.

entries.title: Intermediate Node
entries.description:
In today's session, students read and write to the file system using Node's built-in fs package.

In addition, they learn how to make HTTP GET requests with the request NPM package.

entries.title: Introduction to the NPM Ecosystem
entries.description:
Today's class introduces students to the concept of NPM and package management. 

In particular, it introduces inquirer.js, an NPM package for building command line applications.

entries.title: OOP in Practice
entries.description:
In today's session, students will build the Weather Admin application.

The application accepts a user's name and location, and reports the weather in that location. Users can also retrieve a list of all searches users have performed.

Students will also receive a formal introduction to callbacks.

entries.title: Constructor Functions
entries.description: Today's class introduces students to JavaScript constructors, and how they can be used to dynamically create objects with similar schemas.

entries.title: Constructors and Prototypes
entries.description:
In today's session, students build upon their knowledge of constructors by using them to store user input.

Students will also learn to compose constructors to create complex objects out of small components.

entries.title: Databases with Big Data
entries.description:
Today's class focuses on using MySQL to handle big data. 

In addition, students should also become proficient in creating and using "schema.sql" and "seeds.sql" files, while also learning how to import data from.CSV files.

entries.title: Introduction to Relational Databases
entries.description: In today's session, students will set up MySQL Workbench; learn the basics of relational databases; and learn how to save and retrieve data.

entries.title: Schema-like Databases in Node
entries.description: In today's session, students will connect their Node applications to a MySQL database to persist user input for a fully functional full stack application.

entries.title: Introduction to Node Servers
entries.description: In this class we will provide students with a deep conceptual understanding of server-side code and use vanilla Node.js to create basic servers and handle the response/request cycle manually.

entries.title: Hot Restaurant Activity
entries.description:
Today, students will create an Express based web application for handling restaurant reservation requests. 

In the process of building today's assignment, students will reinforce their understanding of Express Servers, Routing, and AJAX for front-end interaction

entries.title: Express Yourself
entries.description:
Today's session covers how to use Express to simplify request handling. 

Students will also learn to respond differently to GET and POST requests sent to the same route.

entries.title: Abstractions Over SQL
entries.description: Today's session introduces students to the basics of Object-Relational Mapping, a system which allows programmers to more easily collect and to manipulate data from databases using reusable methods.

entries.title: Client-Server Communications
entries.description:
In today's session, students will use everything they've learned to build a database-backed application that handles user input.

They will write a both a front-end, responsible for sending user input to a server, and a back-end, responsible for handling that user input and persisting it to a MySQL database.

entries.title: Introduction to Handlebars
entries.description: Today's session introduces Handlebars, a templating language which allows students to create dynamically generated web pages with minimal reptition of HTML.

entries.title: Intermediate MySQL
entries.description:
Today's session covers using the Sequelize ORM to interact with MySQL databases.

This allows students to avoid the lower-level details of working with MySQL, making for a more robust programming experience.

entries.title: Extras and Loose Ends
entries.description:
In today's session, students will learn how to write belongs-to-many associations, as well as how to write migrations to manage changes to the database.

Students will also gain exposure to bcrypt and password hashing.

entries.title: Sequelized Associations
entries.description:
Today's session introduces students to Sequelize's methods for handling join relations.

In particular, students will learn to write one-to-one and one-to-many relationships, and how to use accessor functions for efficient querying.

entries.title: Introduction to Software Testing
entries.description: Today's lesson will introduce students to the basics of unit testing using Mocha and Chai, and acquaint them with the requirements of their second project.

entries.title: Introduction to Test-Driven Development
entries.description:
In today's class, students will write their tests first, and then their code.

This helps ensure code is correct and safeguards against regressions in the future.

entries.title: Introduction to Functional Testing
entries.description: In this class, we will be introducing student to the principles of user stories and functional testing using Nightmare.js.

entries.title: How Google Reads Websites
entries.description:
Today's session introduces the factors search engines use to determine search rankings.

Students will learn about the major ranking on-page ranking factors; how backlinks influence search rankings; and the importance of clean navigation schemes.

entries.title: "Content Is King"
entries.description: In today's session, students will learn how a website's content influences its search rankings, as well as how to implement accessibility best practices.

entries.title: Web Performance
entries.description: Today's lesson introduces the basics of web performance, including the notion of waterfall charts, and acquaints students with Google Webmaster Tools.

entries.title: Masters of MongoDB
entries.description: Today's session introduces the concept of the NoSQL database with MongoDB, goes over its pros and cons compared with MySQL, and ultimately details all of the required steps to employ MongoDB in future projects.

entries.title: Collecting Data by Crawling the Web
entries.description:
Today's session introduces students to the concept of web scraping, and then how to store data into a MongoDB database using Node and MongoJS. 

By the end of class, students will combine these two skills with an exercise: scraping sites into MongoDB.

entries.title: Defining Relational Schemas with Mongoose
entries.description:
Today's class introduces students to Mongoose, a node package that lends some more power to MongoDB queries. 

With schemas, custom methods and the ability to create relations in a non-relational database, Mongoose will help make MongoDB even more flexible.

entries.title: Introduction to React and Component-Based UI
entries.description: Today's class introduces the basic concepts of ReactJS; JSX; and how to build layouts with a component-based mindset.

entries.title: Component Relationships, States, and Props
entries.description:
Today's session introduces the concepts of states and props; parent-child relationships; and lifecycle events. 

Towards the tail-end of the class, students will work heavily on an application that integrates React with HTTP requests.

entries.title: Using React in a full stack application
entries.description:
Today's class teaches students how to integrate their React applications with a Node, Express, and MongoDB back-end.

Towards the end of class, students will gain exposure to the new concepts of ES6.

entries.title: The Grid System
entries.description:
Today's session is focused on introducing students to the concept of grid-based web design and the utilization of Bootstrap for grid-layouts. 

Towards the end of the session, we will also be covering mobile-responsive web design using media queries and viewports.

entries.title: Publishing Your Websites to Heroku
entries.description: Today's session teaches students how to publish their websites to Heroku.

entries.title: Writing Mobile Applications with React Native
entries.description:
Today's session introduces React Native. This JavaScript framework allows devs to build mobile applications using a syntax similar to ordinary React. 

Some students may choose to focus on review instead. Alternative activities are provided to suit their needs.

entries.title: Consuming API Data in React Native
entries.description:
today's session reviews the React Native principles from 21.1 by creating an mobile app for movie data. This time, we'll build an app that relies on multiple component files, as well as data from an outside sourceâ€”the OMDB API. 

Once again, students will have a choice of working with React Native or participating in a review lecture; those refreshers will focus either on interview questions or a past activity.

entries.title: First Steps on Final Projects
entries.description:
In this lecture, you'll prime your students to conceptualize their final projects. You'll run down the list of expectations and requirements for each of their weekly deliverables.

Aside from that, you and the TAs will stick around to make sure each team has solid idea for their project--they should have one by the end of the class.

entries.title: Basics of Algorithms
entries.description:
Today's session introduces the fundamental concept of algorithm development and efficiency. 

The remainder of class is left for work on projects.

entries.title: Big O and Data Structures
entries.description: Today's lesson will introduce students to the notions of time complexity; Big O analysis; and basic data structures.

entries.title: Sorting Algorithms
entries.description:
Today's session introduces students to sorting algorithms. If time and student interest are appropriate, instructors are free to touch on Lodash. 

The the remainder of class is left for work on projects.

entries.title: Introduction to Ruby/C#
entries.description:
In today's class, students will learn the basics of Ruby or C# by implementing a command-line application. The choice of language is left to the instructor.

They will implement the same application in a different language each day of the week.

entries.title: Introduction to Java
entries.description:
In today's class, students will learn the basics of Java by implementing a command-line application.

They will implement the same application in a different language each day of the week.

entries.title: Introduction to Python
entries.description:
In today's class, students will learn the basics of Python by implementing a command-line application.

They will implement the same application in a different language each day of the week.

entries.title: JavaScript Fundamentals, Pt. 1
entries.description: Today's session introduces variables; many of JavaScript's built-in data structures; and a handful of common functions.

entries.title: JavaScript Fundamentals, Pt. 2
entries.description:
Today's session discusses students to boolean conditions; control flow; and arrays. 

Students will spend roughly the latter half of class using JavaScript to implement Rock-Paper-Scissors.

entries.title: JavaScript Fundamentals, Pt. 3
entries.description:
Today's session introducse students to the syntax for defining and calling functions.

Students also learn how to use objects to define associative data.

entries.title: jQuery Calculator
entries.description:
Today's session takes a closer look at function scope in JavaScript; the this keyword; and jQuery's event-handling mechanisms.

Students spend the latter half of today's session consolidating their knowledge of JavaScript and jQuery by building a fully functional calculator application.

entries.title: Scope and Events
entries.description: Today's session introduces introduces scope and additional common features of jQuery.

entries.title: DOM Manipulation
entries.description: Today's session covers the difference between the DOM and a static HTML document, and introduces common jQuery methods for manipulating it.

entries.title: Technical Interview Preparation
entries.description:
Today's session introduces students to the technical interview as a whole, as well as important problem solving strategies.

In particular, students learn the importance of visualizing problems, interacting with their interviewer, and drafting conceptual solutions.

entries.title: JavaScript Review
entries.description:
Today's class is an opportunity for students to review any JavaScript they don't feel confident about. 

Students will spend the majority of class working through activities from previous points in the curriculum.

entries.title: jQuery and Asynchronous JavaScript
entries.description: Today's session consists of a brief review of jQuery, and then explores the asynchronous nature of JavaScript by way of two useful, common functions: setTimeout and setInterval.

entries.title: Advanced AJAX
entries.description: Today's session takes a closer look at how APIs, JSON, and AJAX work together to enable complex communications between websites.

entries.title: APIs and AJAX
entries.description:
Today's session teaches students how to request information from different websites.

Students gain a stronger grasp on the concept of APIs; working with JSON; and parsing complex JavaScript objects.

entries.title: Consuming Live APIs
entries.description: In today's session, students apply their knowledge of APIs and AJAX to build a "real world" application that fetches and displays articles from the New York Times.

entries.title: Introduction to Client-Side Storage
entries.description: Today's class introduces the concept of data persistence, and the difference between server-side and client- side persistence.

entries.title: Introduction to Firebase
entries.description: Today's session teaches students how to connect to Firebase, and how to wire their application to respond to server-side changes in real time.

entries.title: Building Applications with Firebase
entries.description: In today's session, students will get hands-on experience with the intricacies of handling date and time in JavaScript, as well as round out their exposure to the essential Firebase methods.

entries.title: Project #1 Week #1: All-Class Hackathon
entries.description: Students have all of today's session to work on their projects.

entries.title: Project #1 Week #2: Loose Ends and Whiteboarding
entries.description:
In today's session, students will "warm up" by learning and practicing additional problem-solving strategies in the context of interview questions.

The remainder of class will be dedicated to project work.

entries.title: Project #1 Presentations
entries.description:
Today's session is dedicated to project presentations.

Students and groups will take turns presenting and discussing their work in front of the class.

entries.title: Interview Questions and Project Work
entries.description:
In today's session, students will "warm up" by learning and practicing additional problem-solving strategies in the context of interview questions.

The remainder of class will be dedicated to project work.
